newsitem.title: PERU: Momentum slows in search for Peru crisis solution.
newsitem.headline: Momentum slows in search for Peru crisis solution.

text.p: Pre-Easter optimism had all but vanished on Monday as Marxist rebels accused Peru's government of dragging its feet in talks toward a negotiated solution in the 104-day hostage crisis.
"The slowness is due to the government's intransigence," charged "Comrade Alejandro", a Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) military leader in Peru's eastern jungle.
"The prisoners' issue is still not resolved," he added in a communication with Reuters. "We will stay (in the residence) as long as is necessary to achieve the freedom of our prisoners."

The MRTA's demand for the release of jailed comrades has been the main sticking point since 20-odd rebels led by Nestor Cerpa blasted their way into the Japanese ambassador's residence during a cocktail party on Dec. 17.

Diplomatic and media circles were convinced last week the government and MRTA were close to an agreement involving asylum in Cuba for the hostage-takers, a possible ransom deal and the release of some lower-level prisoners.

But that optimism was dashed over the weekend as the MRTA made a string of tough public statements via the Internet, a banner draped outside the residence and a walkie-talkie conversation between Cerpa and journalists.

A member of a three-man mediation team known as the guarantors' commission, Archbishop Juan Luis Cipriani, also sounded a discouraging note as he said he had no news to report after a day of contacts with the government.

"No problem is eternal and this one will be settled ... Bit by bit, we're getting closer. But I have nothing new to add," he told reporters on Monday night after meeting another guarantor, Canadian ambassador Anthony Vincent. Cipriani snapped at reporters to "go to bed and don't bother us."
Fujimori said over the weekend he was still hopeful of a solution, but was not prepared to shift his position on the prisoners issue.

"There was a lot of speculation during Holy Week that there would be a peaceful solution, but we were conscious that we were not in the final stage, that the conditions were not right," Fujimori said in a television interview.
"Naturally we are hopeful that it will be the soonest possible, but we do not foresee a date."

Although attention has been focused on possibilities for a peaceful solution, crack troops have been training in case of an assault and, according to intelligence reports, the MRTA has slipped an extra 70 fighters into Lima as a potential backup for those inside the residence.

Fujimori met on Monday at the presidential palace with his chief negotiator in the crisis, Domingo Palermo, and the three-man guarantors' commission overseeing negotiations to end Latin America's longest hostage siege.
Japanese government observer Terusuke Terada was also present at the meeting which lasted nearly two hours.

The guarantors have been holding "parallel" meetings with the MRTA and the government during a period of "reflection" since the last and tenth round of face-to-face talks on March 12. Last week's speculation focused on a supposed blueprint proposal by the guarantors to end the crisis.
Cipriani denied on Sunday that talks between the two sides had broken down and called for patience and tolerance on all sides, saying "we are trying to move as fast as possible."
The mainly middle-aged male hostages spent a quiet Easter weekend under the guns of their MRTA captors, with whom they are said to have now formed close personal ties.
While concern centred on the health of the hostages, Alejandro insisted the jungle-trained rebels inside were still in peak condition. "They are doing well, both physically and morally," he said.
